OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and upper limb weakness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 1-month history of experiencing double vision (diplopia), difficulty in climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush her hair. She notes that these symptoms tend to worsen after physical activity but improve significantly after a few hours of rest.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, drinks wine occasionally. Works as a graphic designer.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient denies experiencing any chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or recent infections.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Presence of ptosis (drooping of the right upper eyelid) that worsens with sustained upward gaze.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_Strength: Diminished motor strength observed in the upper extremities, with normal tone and no obvious atrophy.

Electromyography.Findings: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation

Chest_CT.Findings: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

Electromyography.Findings: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation

Chest_CT.Findings: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

model_diagnosis: Doctor: Have you noticed your voice becoming nasal or weak after talking, or any difficulty chewing that worsens with a meal or prolonged use of your jaw muscles? Doctor: Have you started any new medications recently or had a recent infection or surgery, and do you have any personal or family history of autoimmune disease? DIAGNOSIS READY: Myasthenia gravis (generalized)
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: When did your double vision and muscle weakness start, and do they fluctuate or worsen with activity or as the day goes on?
Patient: The double vision and muscle weakness started about a month ago. Yes, they definitely worsen with activity and tend to get better after I've rested for a bit.
Doctor: Doctor: Do you have drooping of either eyelid (ptosis), difficulty swallowing or speaking, or any shortness of breath?
Patient: I haven't noticed any drooping of my eyelids or difficulty swallowing or speaking. Also, I haven't had any shortness of breath.
Doctor: Doctor: How old are you?
Patient: I'm 35 years old.
Doctor: Doctor: Is the double vision present only when both eyes are open and does it go away if you close or cover one eye?
Patient: Yes, the double vision is only there when both eyes are open. It goes away if I close or cover one eye.
Doctor: Doctor: Are your limb weaknesses symmetric and mainly in the shoulder/hip (proximal) muscles or do they affect your hands/feet (distal) more?
Patient: The weakness is mainly in my shoulders and hips. I especially notice it when trying to climb stairs or raise my arms above my head, like when I'm trying to brush my hair.
Doctor: Doctor: Have you noticed any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain anywhere, or is the problem purely weakness?
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain. It's purely weakness.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you noticed your voice becoming nasal or weak after talking, or any difficulty chewing that worsens with a meal or prolonged use of your jaw muscles? Doctor: Have you started any new medications recently or had a recent infection or surgery, and do you have any personal or family history of autoimmune disease? DIAGNOSIS READY: Myasthenia gravis (generalized)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with gait and limb ataxia, and a significant medical history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a follow-up regarding her Crohn disease, and reports new-onset difficulty walking, described by her peers as 'appearing drunk'. She has a significant history of Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, which has escalated in severity, failing to respond to standard therapies. She has been on natalizumab for the past year.

Secondary_Symptoms: Reduced strength in the right upper limb

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, current treatment includes natalizumab for the past year.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

model_diagnosis: Have you used nitrous oxide or other inhaled recreational drugs, or taken neurotoxic medications (eg isoniazid, very high‑dose pyridoxine), and do you have sensory symptoms in your hands as well as your feet or worse balance in the dark/uneven ground? Any family history of ataxia, cardiomyopathy, diabetes, or foot deformities (pes cavus), and do you have palpitations or exertional shortness of breath; REQUEST TEST: Genetic_testing_for_Friedreich_Ataxia_(FXN)_and_expanded_neuropathy_gene_panel. DIAGNOSIS READY: Sensory neuronopathy (large‑fiber dorsal root ganglionopathy) causing sensory ataxia — most consistent with an idiopathic/immune sensory ganglionopathy; consider and rule out hereditary Friedreich ataxia with genetic testing.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: When did your balance and limb coordination problems begin, and have they developed suddenly, gradually, or in steps over time?
Patient: It started gradually a few months ago. Initially, I just felt a bit unsteady on my feet, but it's been getting progressively worse.
Doctor: Doctor: Do you have slurred speech, double vision, or any involuntary eye movements (nystagmus)?
Patient: No, I haven't had slurred speech, double vision, or any involuntary eye movements.
Doctor: Doctor: Do you have numbness, tingling, or reduced sensation in your hands or feet, and does your balance worsen when you close your eyes (Romberg sign)?
Patient: I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling in my hands or feet, but my balance definitely gets worse when I close my eyes.

Doctor: Doctor: Do you have diabetes or take metformin, any history of heavy alcohol use, previous stomach/intestine surgery (eg gastrectomy), follow a strict vegan diet, or notice fatigue, pallor, or easy bruising that might suggest anemia?

Patient: No, I don't have diabetes or take metformin. I don't have a history of heavy alcohol use or any previous stomach/intestine surgery. I'm not on a strict vegan diet, and I haven't noticed fatigue, pallor, or easy bruising.
Doctor: Doctor: How old are you, and have you noticed reduced vibration or position sense in your feet—for example, trouble knowing where your toes are without looking?

Patient: I'm 35 years old. I haven't really paid attention to the vibration or position sense in my feet, but now that you mention it, I might have some trouble knowing where my toes are without looking.
Doctor: Doctor: May I perform a focused neurological exam now, testing vibration and position sense, tendon reflexes, and a Romberg test?
Patient: Yes, of course, you can perform the neurological exam. I want to understand what's happening with my balance and coordination.
Doctor: Doctor: Please close your eyes; I'm going to move your big toe up or down—tell me which direction I move it.
Patient: Down, you moved it down.
Doctor: Doctor: Do any of your close relatives have similar balance or coordination problems, or a known diagnosis of neuropathy or inherited ataxia?
Patient: No, none of my close relatives have similar problems with balance or coordination, and there's no known diagnosis of neuropathy or inherited ataxia in my family.
Doctor: May I test your deep tendon reflexes (knees and ankles) and vibration sense at your ankles now so I can check for peripheral sensory loss?
Patient: Yes, please do. I want to find out if there's any sensory loss that could be causing my balance issues.

Doctor: Doctor: On exam your ankle reflexes are absent, knee reflexes reduced, vibration/proprioception is decreased at the ankles, and Romberg is positive, suggesting a large-fiber sensory peripheral neuropathy causing sensory ataxia. Do you have any leg or foot weakness when walking or climbing stairs, any lightheadedness on standing or urinary/bowel problems, or chronic dry eyes/mouth or other autoimmune symptoms? REQUEST TEST: Nerve_Conduction_Study/EMG; REQUEST TEST: Serum_B12 and Methylmalonic_Acid; REQUEST TEST: Vitamin_E_level; REQUEST TEST: HbA1c.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Do you have burning or shooting pain in your feet, any recent unexplained weight loss, night sweats, chronic cough, a history of smoking, prior chemotherapy, or a known cancer diagnosis?

Patient: No, I don't have burning or shooting pain in my feet, no recent unexplained weight loss, night sweats, chronic cough, and I've never smoked. Also, I've never had chemotherapy or been diagnosed with cancer.

Doctor: Do you have any leg or foot weakness when walking or climbing stairs, lightheadedness on standing, urinary or bowel problems, erectile dysfunction, or other autonomic symptoms? Are you sexually active or have a history of unprotected sex, genital sores, or prior sexually transmitted infections—may I order syphilis and HIV testing? REQUEST TEST: RPR and FTA-ABS; REQUEST TEST: HIV_Ag/Ab
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

Doctor: Doctor: Do you have chronic dry eyes or mouth, swollen salivary glands, or other autoimmune symptoms such as joint pain, photosensitive rash, or unexplained fevers? REQUEST TEST: ANA; REQUEST TEST: Anti-Ro(SSA) and Anti-La(SSB); REQUEST TEST: Paraneoplastic_Antibody_Panel (including anti-Hu); REQUEST TEST: Tissue_Transglutaminase_IgA with total IgA.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

Doctor: Doctor: Do you take any over-the-counter supplements, especially zinc (including denture creams), or high-dose multivitamins? Doctor: Have you had any occupational or environmental exposure to heavy metals (eg, copper, arsenic) or organic solvents, or worked in mining/metal industries? Doctor: REQUEST TEST: Serum_Copper_and_Ceruloplasmin Doctor: REQUEST TEST: MRI_Cervical_and_Thoracic_Spine_with_contrast Doctor: REQUEST TEST: Somatosensory_Evoked_Potentials_(SSEP) Doctor: I'll wait for these results and then integrate them with your exam to reach a diagnosis.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

Doctor: Have you used nitrous oxide or other inhaled recreational drugs, or taken neurotoxic medications (eg isoniazid, very high‑dose pyridoxine), and do you have sensory symptoms in your hands as well as your feet or worse balance in the dark/uneven ground? Any family history of ataxia, cardiomyopathy, diabetes, or foot deformities (pes cavus), and do you have palpitations or exertional shortness of breath; REQUEST TEST: Genetic_testing_for_Friedreich_Ataxia_(FXN)_and_expanded_neuropathy_gene_panel. DIAGNOSIS READY: Sensory neuronopathy (large‑fiber dorsal root ganglionopathy) causing sensory ataxia — most consistent with an idiopathic/immune sensory ganglionopathy; consider and rule out hereditary Friedreich ataxia with genetic testing.

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Your history of fatigable, fluctuating proximal weakness with binocular diplopia plus a positive acetylcholine receptor antibody test is diagnostic of acetylcholine receptor–positive myasthenia gravis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Myasthenia gravis (AChR antibody–positive), generalized form — recommend starting pyridostigmine, urgent neurology referral for consideration of corticosteroids/immunosuppression and baseline pulmonary function testing, and note thymectomy is not indicated acutely given a normal chest CT.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: Do your double vision and limb weakness fluctuate over the day or worsen with use and improve with rest, and do you have drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, or slurred speech?

Patient: Yes, my double vision and limb weakness definitely seem to fluctuate. They do worsen with use and notably improve after I've had some rest. However, I haven't really noticed any drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, or slurred speech.
Doctor: Doctor: Do you have any difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, hoarseness, or choking when eating?
Patient: No, I haven't experienced any difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, hoarseness, or choking when eating.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: When did these symptoms start and how have they progressed (sudden vs gradual over days/weeks/months), is the weakness mainly proximal (shoulder/hip girdle) or distal, and do you have any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain?

Patient: The symptoms started about a month ago and have gradually worsened over that time. The weakness I experience is mainly proximal, especially when trying to climb stairs or raise my arms above my head to brush my hair. I haven't felt any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain, just the weakness and double vision.

Doctor: Doctor: Is your double vision binocular (goes away when you close or cover one eye) and is it mainly horizontal or vertical, and do you notice any subtle droop of an eyelid after looking up for a while? Do you have a history of autoimmune disease or thyroid problems, and have you recently started any new medications or had infections (especially antibiotics like aminoglycosides or fluoroquinolones)?

Patient: Yes, the double vision is binocular; it does go away when I close one eye. I haven't particularly noticed if it's more horizontal or vertical, though. I don't have any history of autoimmune diseases or thyroid problems, and I haven't started any new medications or had any recent infections.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do your symptoms tend to worsen as the day progresses or after prolonged use of the affected muscles (for example, are you noticeably worse in the evening)? REQUEST TEST: Acetylcholine_Receptor_Antibody; REQUEST TEST: Anti-MuSK_Antibody; REQUEST TEST: Single-Fiber_EMG; REQUEST TEST: Chest_CT (to evaluate for thymoma)
Measurement: RESULTS: Acetylcholine Receptor Antibodies: Present (elevated); Chest CT: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you have any trouble holding up your head, facial/bulbar weakness, or exertional shortness of breath, and are your deep tendon reflexes normal on exam? REQUEST TEST: Anti-MuSK_Antibody; REQUEST TEST: Single-Fiber_EMG
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Doctor: Have you tried any medications such as pyridostigmine or corticosteroids/immunosuppressants, and if so did your symptoms improve?
Patient: No, I haven't tried any medications like pyridostigmine or corticosteroids/immunosuppressants yet.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Your history of fatigable, fluctuating proximal weakness with binocular diplopia plus a positive acetylcholine receptor antibody test is diagnostic of acetylcholine receptor–positive myasthenia gravis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Myasthenia gravis (AChR antibody–positive), generalized form — recommend starting pyridostigmine, urgent neurology referral for consideration of corticosteroids/immunosuppression and baseline pulmonary function testing, and note thymectomy is not indicated acutely given a normal chest CT.

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Based on the progressive focal neurologic deficits, MRI findings typical of multifocal demyelination without enhancement, and prior JCV seropositivity while on natalizumab, this is most consistent with natalizumab-associated Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy. DIAGNOSIS READY: Natalizumab-associated Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (JC virus reactivation).
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: Can you tell me when your gait and limb ataxia started, whether it came on suddenly or gradually, and how it has progressed since it began?

Patient: It started gradually about a few months ago and seems to have gotten slightly worse over time. At first, it was just a bit of unsteadiness, but now I'm having a harder time controlling my movements and keeping my balance.

Doctor: Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms—slurred speech, double vision, numbness or weakness, tremors, bladder/bowel changes, memory problems, or abnormal eye movements—and please tell me your significant medical history (chronic illnesses, meds, alcohol or drug use, prior cancer or chemo)?

Patient: I haven't noticed any slurred speech or double vision, but I do feel a bit of weakness, especially in my right arm. No changes in bladder or bowel control, no memory problems or abnormal eye movements either. As for my medical history, I've been dealing with Crohn's disease for the past two years and have been on natalizumab for the last year. I don't use alcohol or drugs, and I have no history of cancer or chemo.
Doctor: Doctor: Have you had any headaches, fevers, recent infections, or new headaches since the ataxia began?
Patient: No, I haven't had any headaches, fevers, or recent infections that I'm aware of since the ataxia started.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you had anti–JC virus antibody testing or a recent brain MRI, and have you noticed any changes in thinking, personality, vision, or any seizures? REQUEST TEST: Brain_MRI_with_and_without_contrast; REQUEST TEST: CSF_JC_Virus_PCR

Measurement: RESULTS: MRI_Brain: Findings consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML). Comments include T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML. NORMAL READINGS for CSF_JC_Virus_PCR, as results for this test are not provided in the provided data.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you had anti–JC virus antibody testing (JCV index) and do you know the result, and have you continued natalizumab or had any recent dosing changes or other immunosuppressive treatments?

Patient: Yes, I had the anti-JC virus antibody test before starting natalizumab, and it was positive. I've continued on natalizumab without any dosing changes or additions of other immunosuppressive treatments since then.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Based on the progressive focal neurologic deficits, MRI findings typical of multifocal demyelination without enhancement, and prior JCV seropositivity while on natalizumab, this is most consistent with natalizumab-associated Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy. DIAGNOSIS READY: Natalizumab-associated Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (JC virus reactivation).

problem_info.question: A 55-year-old woman presented to the dermatology clinic with a 1-year history of skin darkening on her face. Two years before presentation, she had started applying a skin-lightening cream containing hydroquinone to her face daily to treat melasma. On physical examination, bluish-brown patches with background erythema and telangiectasias were observed on the cheeks, nasal bridge, and perioral region, with lesser involvement on the forehead (left). Dermoscopy of the affected areas revealed hyperchromic, pinpoint macules (middle). A skin-biopsy sample from the left cheek showed extracellular deposition of yellow-brown, banana-shaped bodies in the dermis (right, hematoxylin and eosin stain). What is the most likely diagnosis?
problem_info.patient_info: For your role as a patient, you are a 55-year-old woman who has noticed your skin darkening on your face over the past year. You began using a skin-lightening cream containing hydroquinone daily two years ago to address melasma. You've observed bluish-brown patches on your cheeks, nasal bridge, and around your mouth, with some patches also appearing on your forehead. These patches have a background of redness and you've noticed some small, visible blood vessels in these areas. You haven't seen any specific test readings but are aware of the changes in your skin's appearance and texture.
problem_info.physical_exams: The information extracted from the case report relevant to instrument readings and test results includes: 1. Dermoscopy findings: Hyperchromic, pinpoint macules observed in the affected areas. 2. Skin biopsy results: Extracellular deposition of yellow-brown, banana-shaped bodies in the dermis, as revealed by hematoxylin and eosin stain.

dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: How long have these facial lesions been present, did they start after any skin injury or contact with soil/vegetation, and are they itchy, painful, or draining?

Patient: The patches started showing up gradually over the past year, with no specific injury or contact with soil or vegetation that I can recall. They're not itchy or painful and there's no drainage; it's more the appearance and the discoloration that bother me.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Are there similar patches on your chest, back, or elsewhere on the body, do they worsen with heat, sweating, or sun exposure, and have you used any creams (especially topical steroids or antifungals) or taken any treatments that changed them?

Patient: There aren't similar patches on my chest or back, just on my face mainly - the cheeks, nasal bridge, around my mouth, and some on my forehead. They do seem to darken a bit with sun exposure, which is why I started using a skin-lightening cream with hydroquinone daily about two years ago, but I haven’t used any steroids or antifungals. I haven’t noticed any significant changes with the treatments I've tried.
Doctor: DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis (hydroquinone-induced ochronosis)

problem_info.question: A 9-year-old boy who had recently emigrated from Brazil presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of neck swelling, fevers, and weight loss. On physical examination, there was fixed, tender lymphadenopathy in the posterior auricular, submandibular, and occipital chains. Laboratory testing was notable for peripheral eosinophilia. Tests for cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, and human immunodeficiency virus were negative. CT scan of the neck showed hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides. Lymph node biopsy results are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
problem_info.patient_info: For your role as a patient actor, here's the minimal information you need to convey your symptoms accurately: - **Age and Background**: You are a 9-year-old boy who recently moved from Brazil. - **Symptoms**: - You've been experiencing swelling in your neck for the past 3 weeks. - You've had fevers during this period. - You've noticed that you've lost some weight without trying. - **Physical Discomfort**: - The swollen areas in your neck, specifically behind your ears (posterior auricular), under your jaw (submandibular), and at the back of your head (occipital), are tender to touch and don't move when you try to push them. - **Medical Tests and Results** (which you're not aware of, but might influence your portrayal): - You've had some blood tests done, but you don't know the details. - You've undergone a CT scan of your neck, but you haven't been told the results. - You've had a biopsy of the lymph nodes in your neck, but again, you don't know the outcomes. Remember, your character is aware of the symptoms and the discomfort they cause but does not know the specific medical terms, test readings, or the diagnosis.
problem_info.physical_exams: Laboratory testing results: - Peripheral eosinophilia present - Tests for cryptococcus: Negative - Tests for histoplasmosis: Negative - Tests for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Negative Imaging results: - CT scan of the neck: Hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides

model_diagnosis:
Given your origin from Brazil, weeks of febrile illness with painful cervical lymphadenopathy, granulomatous lymph node histology and the characteristic multiple-budding "pilot-wheel" yeast on fungal stain, this is most consistent with paracoccidioidomycosis due to Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.  
DIAGNOSIS READY: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Paracoccidioides brasiliensis).
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you lived in or traveled to rural areas of South America (especially Brazil, Colombia, or Venezuela) recently or in the past?
Patient: Yes, actually, I moved here from Brazil a couple of months ago.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you had chronic cough, weight loss, fevers or painful ulcerative lesions in your mouth or throat?
Patient: I've had fevers and I did lose some weight recently, but I haven't really had a cough or any sores in my mouth or throat.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you noticed any painless swollen lumps in your neck or armpits (lymph nodes) or any skin lesions or ulcers that appeared recently?

Patient: Yes, my neck has these swollen spots that have been there for like three weeks. They're kind of painful when I touch them, especially behind my ears and under my jaw. I haven't seen any skin ulcers or anything like that though.

Doctor: Given your origin from Brazil, weeks of febrile illness with painful cervical lymphadenopathy, granulomatous lymph node histology and the characteristic multiple-budding "pilot-wheel" yeast on fungal stain, this is most consistent with paracoccidioidomycosis due to Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.  
DIAGNOSIS READY: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Paracoccidioides brasiliensis).

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Do you have any small firm bluish‑black papules or a “caviar‑like” gritty texture within the dark patches, and did the pigmentation continue or worsen after you stopped using the cream? REQUEST TEST: Punch_skin_biopsy_of_an_affected_area for histology to look for ochronotic deposits. DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis due to long‑term topical hydroquinone use.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: Hello — please tell me what symptoms you're having, when they began, and how severe they feel.

Patient: Hello, Doctor. Over the past year, I've noticed my skin on my face becoming darker, especially with bluish-brown patches on my cheeks, nasal bridge, and around my mouth. Even my forehead has some spots. These areas sometimes look red and I've seen some small blood vessels showing through as well.
Doctor: Have you used any skin‑lightening creams or cosmetic products (especially hydroquinone), topical steroids, or home remedies on your face for an extended period?
Patient: Yes, I started using a skin-lightening cream that contains hydroquinone daily about two years ago to help with my melasma.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you have any small firm bluish‑black papules or a “caviar‑like” gritty texture within the dark patches, and did the pigmentation continue or worsen after you stopped using the cream? REQUEST TEST: Punch_skin_biopsy_of_an_affected_area for histology to look for ochronotic deposits. DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis due to long‑term topical hydroquinone use.

dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: What brings you in today — please describe your main symptom, when it began, and how severe it is on a scale of 1–10.

Patient: I came because my neck has been really swollen for about three weeks now. It started kind of small, but it's gotten bigger. If I had to say how bad it feels, maybe like a 6? It's really sore, especially when I touch it.
Doctor: Doctor: Is the swelling on one side or both, and exactly where is it located—under the jaw, along the side of the neck, or in the front?
Patient: It's on both sides, doctor. The swelling is right behind my ears, under my jaw, and also at the back of my head.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you had any fever, night sweats, unintended weight loss, or significant fatigue, and do you have sore throat, ear pain, scalp itching or rash, or recent contact with cats or other animals?

Patient: Yes, I've had fevers on and off since the swelling started. And I've noticed that I've lost some weight without really trying. No sore throat or ear pain, but sometimes I feel really tired. I haven't been near any animals recently.
Doctor: Doctor: Have you had night sweats, about how much weight have you lost, and have you noticed swollen lymph nodes elsewhere such as your armpits or groin?
Patient: I've had some night sweats, yes. I'm not sure how much weight I've lost, but my clothes feel looser. I haven't noticed any swelling like this in my armpits or groin, just my neck.
Doctor: How old are you, and are the swollen areas firm or soft, tender or painless, movable or fixed, and is the overlying skin red or warm?
Patient: I'm 9 years old. The swollen areas are pretty firm, and they're tender when I touch them. They don't move much when I try to push them, and the skin doesn't look red or feel warm.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Has anyone in your household had tuberculosis or a persistent cough, and have you traveled recently or been around someone with a long-standing cough?
Patient: No, nobody at home has had tuberculosis or a persistent cough. We moved from Brazil not too long ago, but I haven't been around anyone with a long-standing cough either.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you taken any antibiotics or other medicines for the swollen neck, and if so did the swelling or fevers get better, worse, or stay the same?
Patient: No, I haven't taken any antibiotics or other medicines for this. So, the swelling and the fevers have just stayed the same.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you have any abdominal pain or a feeling of fullness, easy bruising or bleeding, or unusual paleness? REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential, ESR_CRP, LDH, Neck_Ultrasound, Chest_X-Ray.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Have the lymph nodes been steadily getting larger, and about how big would you say they are (in centimeters) when you feel them? REQUEST TEST: EBV_serology (VCA IgM/IgG, EBNA)
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Doctor: Have you had any recent scalp sores, lice, bumps, or skin infections on your head or behind your ears that might explain the occipital swelling?
Patient: No, I haven't had any scalp sores, lice, bumps, or skin infections. Nothing like that has happened recently.

Doctor: Doctor: Have the lymph nodes been steadily enlarging over the three weeks and do they feel matted (stuck together) or separate? REQUEST TEST: Interferon_Gamma_Release_Assay_(Quantiferon) and REQUEST TEST: Excisional_Lymph_Node_Biopsy_with_histology_AFB_and_culture.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: DIAGNOSIS READY: Reactive (benign) cervical/occipital lymphadenitis, most consistent with a self-limited viral or nonspecific lymphadenitis.
